cdata.constitutionalAuthorityStatementText: [Congressional Record Volume 169, Number 30 (Tuesday, February 14, 2023)][House]From the Congressional Record Online through the Government Publishing Office [www.gpo.gov]By Mr. KILMER:H.R. 1015.Congress has the power to enact this legislation pursuantto the following:Article I, Section 8, Clause 3The single subject of this legislation is:Congressional Gold Medal (To award a Congressional GoldMedal to the United States Army Dustoff crews of the VietnamWar)[Page H841]

item.title: Dustoff Crews of the Vietnam War Congressional Gold Medal Act

item.text: Referred to the House Committee on Financial Services.

item.fullName: Del. Radewagen, Aumua Amata Coleman [R-AS-At Large]
Del. Sablan, Gregorio Kilili Camacho [D-MP-At Large]

item.name: Emergency medical services and trauma care

cdata.text:
Dustoff Crews of the Vietnam War Congressional Gold Medal Act

This bill provides for the award of a single Congressional Gold Medal to Dustoff crews (helicopter air ambulance crews) of the Vietnam War in recognition of their heroic military service.

bill.title: Dustoff Crews of the Vietnam War Congressional Gold Medal Act

item.title: Dustoff Crews of the Vietnam War Congressional Gold Medal Act
Dustoff Crews of the Vietnam War Congressional Gold Medal Act
To award a Congressional Gold Medal to the United States Army Dustoff crews of the Vietnam War, collectively, in recognition of their extraordinary heroism and life-saving actions in Vietnam.

latestAction.text: Referred to the House Committee on Financial Services.

dublinCore.dc:rights: Pursuant to Title 17 Section 105 of the United States Code, this file is not subject to copyright protection and is in the public domain.
dublinCore.dc:contributor: Congressional Research Service, Library of Congress
dublinCore.dc:description: This file contains bill summaries and statuses for federal legislation. A bill summary describes the most significant provisions of a piece of legislation and details the effects the legislative text may have on current law and federal programs. Bill summaries are authored by the Congressional Research Service (CRS) of the Library of Congress. As stated in Public Law 91-510 (2 USC 166 (d)(6)), one of the duties of CRS is "to prepare summaries and digests of bills and resolutions of a public general nature introduced in the Senate or House of Representatives". For more information, refer to the User Guide that accompanies this file.
